g.text: bactericidal activity for integrated air cleaning
Air Ô¨Åltration has become an essential need for passive pollution control. However, most of
the commercial air puriÔ¨Åers rely on dense Ô¨Åbrous Ô¨Ålters, which have good particulate matter
(PM) removal capability but poor biocidal effect. Here we present the photocatalytic bac-
tericidal properties of a series of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and their potentials in air
pollution control and personal protection. SpeciÔ¨Åcally, a zinc-imidazolate MOF (ZIF-8)
efÔ¨Åciency) in saline within 2 h of simulated solar irradiation. Mechanistic studies indicate that
centers within ZIF-8 via ligand to metal charge transfer
(LMCT) are responsible for oxygen-reduction related reactive oxygen species (ROS) pro-
duction, which is the dominant disinfection mechanism. Air Ô¨Ålters fabricated from ZIF-8 show
remarkable performance for integrated pollution control, with >99.99% photocatalytic killing
efÔ¨Åciency against airborne bacteria in 30 min and 97%PMremoval. This work may shed light
on designing new porous solids with photocatalytic antibiotic capability for public health
Beijing Key Laboratory of Photoelectronic/Electrophotonic Conversion Materials, Key Laboratory of Cluster Science, Ministry of Education, School of
Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, 100081 Beijing, China. Correspondence and requests for materials should be addressed
